definition[0]: to put your arms around someone and hold them in a friendly or loving way
definition[1]: to eagerly accept a new idea, opinion, religion etc
example[2]: We hope these regions will embrace democratic reforms.
example[3]: Most West European countries have embraced the concept of high-speed rail networks with enthusiasm.
definition[2]: to include something as part of a subject, discussion etc
example[4]: This course embraces several different aspects of psychology.
explanation[0]: Embrace is a reciprocal verb This type of verb is used when saying that two or more people or things do something that involves both or all of them It does not need to have an object  In this sentence, embrace is intransitive and does not have an object
explanation[1]: In these sentences, embrace is transitive
definition[3]: the act of holding someone close to you, especially as a sign of love
example[8]: They held each other in a tender embrace.
